Award.AwardTitle: NUE: EXPOSING ENGINEERING STUDENTS TO NANOSCIENCE AND NANOTECHNOLOGY AT THE UNIVERSITY OF NORTH DAKOTA

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal, NUE: Exposing Engineering Students to Nanoscience and Nanotechnology at the University of North Dakota (UND), under the direction of Dr. Naima Kaabouch, outlines a detailed project to establish and develop nanoscience and nanotechnology (NSNT) undergraduate education in the state of North Dakota. As a part of the leading comprehensive university in the state, a UND faculty team will develop a sequence of NSNT courses in the College of Engineering & Mines and the College of Arts & Sciences. These courses will include (1)fundamental classroom sessions coupled with laboratory experiments that focus on the structure and theory of nanomaterials and the fundamentals of machines utilizing nanodevices; (2) advanced classroom sessions that focus on the properties and development of nanomaterials and fabrication of nanodevices as well as their applications in the engineering field. The ethical and societal implications of NSNT and an assessment of the feasibility of nanotechnology development will also be included. The multidisciplinary faculty team assembled to develop these courses originates from the departments of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Physics & Astrophysics, and Educational Foundations & Research.

The development of NSNT is one of the main goals in the strategic plan of the University of North Dakota. The proposed NUE courses will dramatically enhance the university's effort, and thus will promote North Dakota nanoscience and nanotechnology education to a new level. Therefore, the proposed effort will benefit U.S. industry by providing the much needed training for our engineers. Additionally, underrepresented minorities will be exposed to this emerging NSNT field, which is crucial to satisfy the national need for
developing a diverse and internationally competitive workforce in this NSNT field. This will be done by providing educational opportunities in this emerging field to Native Americans in the state of North Dakota. North Dakota is one of the states with the highest percentage of Native Americans. This way, more underrepresented minority students can be encouraged to consider science and engineering as career options.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanoscience and nanotechnology is a maturing field of study that has grown rapidly beyond the formative stages of exploration and experimentation in interdisciplinarity. For this project, faculty in physics, chemistry, mechanical engineering, and electrical engineering came together to develop and deliver coursework that was designed to introduce students to the fundamental concepts of nanoscience and nanotechnology as well as to implement pedagogically effective practices in teaching nanoscience and nanotechnology. Approximately 27 students enrolled in the first course, Nanoengineering and Nanoscience, across two semesters. This course covered the fundamentals of nanoscience and nanoparticles based on their physical and electronic structures. Approximately 34 students enrolled in the second course, Engineering Applications of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology, across two semesters. This course covered mechanical, electrical, and chemical properties of nanomaterials, and engineering applications of nanoscience and nanotechnology.  It also covered ethical, social, and environmental impacts of nanomaterials. Students could take the course in a face-to-face, campus-based format or via an asynchronous, distance platform.

Faculty developed course objectives, lesson plans, course materials, lectures, homework assignments, and tests for both courses. They then organized and delivered all of this material to students.  The coursework served as an organizational framework for helping students understand the social implications and ethics of responsibility in carrying out work in the fields of nanoscience and nanotechnology as well as in each of the principal disciplines that were represented in this project. The curriculum was further enhanced around the application of the core concepts, partially as a means to best prepare students for careers that require nanoscience and nanotechnology knowledge and skill acquisition, but also as a means to advance cutting-edge science and engineering initiatives. In the first year, we learned that there was congruence in how students considered the sources of their awareness of, exposure to, and motivations for investigating nanotechnology. They relied quite a bit on learning in formal settings and maintained a focus on in-class activities for sources of information. In the Engineering Applications course, students began to look beyond the course by the end of the semester for more information about nanoscience and nanotechnology, and their motivation to learn more about nanotechnology was enhanced in several ways.

One of the key pedagogical components of the courses that were developed for this project was the implementation of problem-based learning (PBL). Case studies served as capstone projects and ways in which students could collaborate in an interdisciplinary manner, much like the faculty teaching the courses. The case study products that resulted from this project can certainly be used as examples of how to pedagogically approach teaching in an interdisciplinary setting.

In addition to developing nanoscience and nanotechnology coursework, faculty designed, developed, and delivered outreach activities to Native American high school and tribal college students in North Dakota. In the first year of the project, the faculty participated in a “Sunday Academy” series that was designed to generate student interest in math, science, and engineering programs. Two lesson activities were developed by faculty for the participating students: 1) “Why does hair turn grey, and how big is it at the nanoscale?” where students investigated the reasons why hair turns grey. They measured the diameter of human hairs and calculated average and standard deviation in nanometer units.

2) “Discovering the properties of nanomaterials” where students learned how to use an Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) instrument to record an image of a CD-ROM. They learned how binary information is stored in this type of memory.

In the second year of the project, faculty collaborated with North Dakota tribal colleges to host outreach activities for Native American high school students. There were two hands-on experimental projects that were prepared and delivered to the participating students: 1) “How Good are Sunscreens?” where students investigated the protection efficiency of sunscreens against UV light including UVA and UVB. They tested different sunscreen samples with different Sun Protection Factor (SPF) ratings. 2) “Light and Color Project” where students worked with light as electromagnetic radiation within a certain range of electromagnetic spectrum. They used an equilateral triangle prism to break light up into its constituent spectral colors (i.e. the colors of the rainbow) and they also used filters of different colors to demonstrate that it is possible to add and subtract colors. In another activity, the faculty used a solar cell car to demonstrate how solar cells work.

 The results of this projects were disseminated through 4 proceedings papers and over four presentations at national and international conferences.
